qas.question: What is shared by most treaties since the late 19th century?
What is the beginning of a typical treaty called?
Why are long sentences in a modern preamble formatted into multiple paragraphs?
Each paragraph of a modern preamble typically begins with which part of speech?
In addition to describing the parties and their joint objectives, what else does a modern preamble typically summarize?

answers.text: any underlying events (such as a war)

context: Since the late 19th century, most treaties have followed <a0_0>a fairly consistent format<a0_0/>. A treaty typically begins with <a1_0>a preamble<a1_0/> describing the contracting parties and their joint objectives in executing the treaty, as well as summarizing <a4_0>any underlying events (such as a war)<a4_0/>. Modern preambles are sometimes structured as a single very long sentence formatted into multiple paragraphs for <a2_0>readability<a2_0/>, in which each of the paragraphs begins with <a3_0>a verb<a3_0/> (desiring, recognizing, having, and so on).
